entry.title: Encrypted Wallet Backward Compatibility
entry.summary: In this email conversation, Gavin Andresen discusses potential security issues with unencrypted keypools in a Bitcoin wallet. He suggests that an attacker could delete encrypted keypool keys and insert unencrypted ones to gain access to the user's Bitcoins. However, it is noted that if unencrypted keys are loaded but not added to address books or keypools, they can still receive Bitcoins without being shown to the user. The discussion then moves on to the issue of breaking backup scripts when encrypting wallets. It is suggested that truncating the original wallet.dat file and creating an encrypted version may solve this problem. However, this solution only works on Linux and Mac, and renaming the file could cause problems for users who are accustomed to the original filename. Finally, there is a suggestion to add a minimum version requirement to the wallet.dat file to prevent any potential downgrade issues after future updates.
